content: The technical details of this are way beyond me, but instinctively the idea that things can be parts of themselves is pretty natural: fractals are everywhere in nature. So this seems like someething which should be possible and useful. is this construction related to non-wellfounded sets?
I'll have to trust you on the accessibility part, but how does this avoid running into the same size issues as the usual Cat∈Cat\mathrm{Cat} \in \mathrm{Cat}Cat∈Cat?

naso evangelou-oost said:

The technical details of this are way beyond me, but instinctively the idea that things can be parts of themselves is pretty natural: fractals are everywhere in nature.

Isn't that more about containing isomorphic copies of itself? That's of course completely unproblematic, but as far as I understand that's not what's happening here.

The relationship between the accessibility rank of a monad and the accessibility rank of the category of algebras is a little bit fiddly. You might want to look at theorem 2.18 in my model categories paper: http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/2/31-02abs.html

As you have observed, the key to this phenomenon is Gabriel–Ulmer duality. I don't think there's anything surprising or paradoxical if you stick to the small categories picture. But I do object somewhat to the notion that the correct notion of morphism of locally κ\kappaκ-presentable categories is a left adjoint functor that preserves κ\kappaκ-presentable objects – this seems unnatural, though it does amount to taking the opposite of the category where the morphisms are κ\kappaκ-accessible right adjoint functors...

Not every condition of the form ``let CCC be the category of all ...'' determines a well-defined category. In this case, the condition:
Tim Campion said:

Let κ≥ω\kappa \geq \omegaκ≥ω be a regular cardinal. Let PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ denote the ∞\infty∞-category of locally κ\kappaκ-presentable ∞\infty∞-categories...

needs a qualifier - like ``small'' - else you run into the problem that you have observed. The elaborate structure in this example is a red herring though, the category of categories with finite products has finite products, etc. :smile:

Steve Awodey said:

Not every condition of the form ``let CCC be the category of all ...'' determines a well-defined category. In this case, the condition:
Tim Campion said:

Let κ≥ω\kappa \geq \omegaκ≥ω be a regular cardinal. Let PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ denote the ∞\infty∞-category of locally κ\kappaκ-presentable ∞\infty∞-categories...

needs a qualifier - like ``small'' - else you run into the problem that you have observed. The elaborate structure in this example is a red herring though, the category of categories with finite products has finite products, etc. :smile:

I'm not sure I understand the point about size. The category of small categories with finite products _does_ have finite products, but it is not a small category, so it is not an object of itself. The category of locally small categories with finite products has finite products, but it is not locally small, so it is not an object of itself.

But in the case I'm discussing, the "smallness" condition is precisely the local κ\kappaκ-presentability condition. So the striking thing is that PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is a category of _all_ categories-with-smallness-condition, but PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ itself satisfies the _same_ smallness condition as its objects!

So it seems to me that from the perspective of smallness, there is something genuinely surprising going on here which doesn't show up in things like "categories with finite products".

Zhen Lin Low said:

As you have observed, the key to this phenomenon is Gabriel–Ulmer duality. I don't think there's anything surprising or paradoxical if you stick to the small categories picture. But I do object somewhat to the notion that the correct notion of morphism of locally κ\kappaκ-presentable categories is a left adjoint functor that preserves κ\kappaκ-presentable objects – this seems unnatural, though it does amount to taking the opposite of the category where the morphisms are κ\kappaκ-accessible right adjoint functors...

In the past I have in some sense agreed with this -- I have generally assumed that PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is never really the category I want to understand or think about, but only something which is introduced as a technical tool to understand more "intrinsically interesting" categories like PrLPr^LPrL (the category of all locally presentable categories and all left adjoint functors).

Of course, the notion of the "right" morphisms to consider is only truly justified by what you can do with them.

But maybe I'll push back from a purely conceptual perspective -- I think there's a case to be made that when considering the collection of locally κ\kappaκ-presentable categories as such, it _is_ very natural to restrict the morphisms to be left adjoints which preserve κ\kappaκ-compact objects. I can think of several reasons (perhaps not wholly independent from one another):

  1. At a very basic level, when restricting the objects of PrLPr^LPrL to be the objects of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​, it seems very natural to also restrict the morphisms. One indication of this is that the full subcategory of PrLPr^LPrL on the objects of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ has an essentially small set of objects, but is not even locally essentially small! When was the last time you thought about a non-locally-small category with a small set of objects?

  2. As you say, this condition is equivalent to requiring the right adjoints to be κ\kappaκ-accessible. So to the extent that it's natural to consider the category AccκAcc_\kappaAccκ​ of κ\kappaκ-accessible categories and κ\kappaκ-accessible functors, it's also natural to consider PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​. For instance, the morphisms of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ are precisely the morphisms in the ambient 2-category AccκAcc_\kappaAccκ​ which have right adjoints in AccκAcc_\kappaAccκ​.

  3. PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is a very nice category -- as I've mentioned, it's complete and cocomplete, monadic over CatCatCat, even locally κ\kappaκ-presentable. The full subcategory of PrLPr^LPrL on the same objects has none of these properties.

Tobias Schmude said:

I'll have to trust you on the accessibility part, but how does this avoid running into the same size issues as the usual Cat∈Cat\mathrm{Cat} \in \mathrm{Cat}Cat∈Cat?

That's what I'd like to know!

Tim Campion said:

I think it's correct, though. Assuming this, the next thing to ponder is whether there is a category-theoretic sense in which "PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is an object of itself". Something more "intrinsic" than saying "PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ lies in the image of the forgetful functor PrκL→CATPr^L_\kappa \to CATPrκL​→CAT".

Maybe one could say that PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is a model of some type theory satisfying type-in-type.
The analogue of Russell's paradox would only arise if the "subcategory of κ\kappaκ-presentable categories which do not contain themselves" is also κ\kappaκ-presentable, and I would bet that it isn't.

I think the problem disappears if you specify precisely from which universe the objects of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ are drawn. PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ itself should live in a higher universe, so it can't be an element of itself, although it is equivalent, as a category, to an object of itself.

Leopold Schlicht said:

I think the problem disappears if you specify precisely from which universe the objects of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ are drawn. PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ itself should live in a higher universe, so it can't be an element of itself, although it is equivalent, as a category, to an object of itself.

I suppose you could do that if you view this as a problem. But to me, what's interesting is that it's something which looks like it should be a problem but... apparently it is not a problem! (i.e. there is no contradiction here)

Leopold Schlicht Oh, I think I see what you mean now -- you're saying that this story actually would be a problem if the object - set of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ were literally an element of (a tuple packaging it with its morphisms and composition to form a category, which is an element of) the object set of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​. You're pointing out that this is not literally the case... which is an important point!

The precise reason why will be sensitive to how things are formalized. But if we work in ZFC with one universe VλV_\lambdaVλ​, and if we define the object-set of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ to comprise certain categories whose object sets are subsets of VλV_\lambdaVλ​, and if we encode categories as certain 4-tuples of sets (objects, morphisms, composition, identities), and if we just assume that 4-tuples are part of our basic language rather than worrying about how Kuratowski ordered pairs work, then the elements of PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ are certain elements of $$V_{\lambda+1}$, and PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is an element of Vλ+2V_{\lambda+2}Vλ+2​. And some (in fact most) of its elements are too big to live in VλV_\lambdaVλ​, so they are properly in Vλ+1V_{\lambda+1}Vλ+1​, so PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​ is properly in Vλ+2V_{\lambda+2}Vλ+2​. So it's not an element of itself.

We might alternatively think about whether (Rexκidem)κ(Rex^{idem}_\kappa)_\kappa(Rexκidem​)κ​ is an element of (Rexκidem)κ(Rex^{idem}_\kappa)_\kappa(Rexκidem​)κ​, where the objects of RexκidemRex^{idem}_\kappaRexκidem​ are certain elements of VλV_\lambdaVλ​. The answer is no for size reasons -- (Rexκidem)κ(Rex^{idem}_\kappa)_\kappa(Rexκidem​)κ​ is essentially small, but not literally small, so it doesn't live in VλV_\lambdaVλ​.

But what if we impose some skeletality condition? For instance, define Rex~κidem\widetilde{Rex}_\kappa^{idem}Rexκidem​ to comprise those objects of RexκidemRex_\kappa^{idem}Rexκidem​ whose von Neumann rank is minimal in their equivalence class. Then... well, (Rex~κidem)κ(\widetilde{Rex}_\kappa^{idem})_\kappa(Rexκidem​)κ​ is again large even though it's essentially small, so again it is trivially not an element of itself.

It should be that PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​, although an object of itself, is not a κ\kappaκ-presentable object of itself. So the left adjoint functor ⟨PrκL⟩:Spaces→PrκL\langle Pr^L_\kappa \rangle : Spaces \to Pr^L_\kappa⟨PrκL​⟩:Spaces→PrκL​, which carries ∗∈Spaces\ast \in Spaces∗∈Spaces to PrκL∈PrκLPr^L_\kappa \in Pr^L_\kappaPrκL​∈PrκL​, is not a morphism in PrκLPr^L_\kappaPrκL​. I think this fact ought to be relevant to various paradox-evasion maneuvers.
